tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship."
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
This means the writer was waiting for Yahweh to help him.

tn.ref: he listened to me ... heard my cry
tn.text: These mean the same thing, and can be combined into one statement. AT: "he listened to me when I called out to him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: out of a horrible pit, out of the miry clay
tn.text: These two metaphors mean the same thing. The writer's danger is spoken of as if it was a deadly pit full of mud. This emphasizes the danger. AT: "from being trapped in a horrible pit full of sticky mud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he set my feet on a rock
tn.text: Here "my feet" refers to the writer, and "a rock" refers a place of safety. AT: "he provided safety for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He has put a new song in my mouth
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "He has taught me the words to a new song" or 2) "He has given me a new reason to sing."
Here "my mouth" refers to the writer. AT: "in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The noun "praise" can be stated as a verb. AT: "a song to praise our God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "see it" refers to hearing the writer sing his song about what God has done for him. AT: "Many people will hear me tell what Yahweh has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Blessed is the man who makes Yahweh his trust
tn.text: "Blessed is the man who trusts in Yahweh" or "Those who trust in Yahweh are blessed"
This refers to the people who are proud. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The Hebrew word is unclear. Possible meanings are 1) "lies" or 2) "false gods" (UDB).

tn.ref: your thoughts which are about us cannot be numbered
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "no one can count all the things you think about us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: cannot be numbered ... more than could be counted
tn.text: These phrases mean essentially the same thing. The first is stated in negative form, and the second is stated in positive form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: You have no delight in sacrifice or offering
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to show that these things were not the most important to God. AT: "Sacrifices and other offerings are not the things that delight you most" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here "ears" refers to the ability to hear. AT: "you have enabled me to hear your commands" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have not required burnt offerings or sin offerings
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to show that these things were not the most important to God. AT: "animals burned on the altar and other offerings for our sins are not what you require most" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This refers to a scroll on which was written the word of Yahweh. AT: "the written scroll" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: your laws are in my heart
tn.text: Here "my heart" refers to the inner being of the writer. AT: "I am always thinking about your laws within my inner being" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I have proclaimed good news of your righteousness in the great assembly
tn.text: "I have told a large assembly of people the good news of your righteousness."
This refers to the good news that God rescues his people. AT: "good news that because you are righteous, you rescue your people" ([[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: my lips have not kept back from doing this
tn.text: Here "my lips" refers to the writer's speech. AT: "I have not stopped myself from proclaiming these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I have not concealed your righteousness in my heart
tn.text: "I have not kept your righteousness a secret." This can also be stated in positive form. AT: "I have openly told every one about your righteousness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Here this refers to the writer's inner being. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I have not concealed your covenant faithfulness or your trustworthiness from the great assembly
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I have told everyone in the great assembly about your covenant faithfulness or your trustworthiness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This abstract noun can be stated as an action. AT: "how faithful you are to keep your promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This abstract noun can be stated as an action. AT: "how trustworthy you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: let your covenant faithfulness and your trustworthiness always preserve me
tn.text: Here "covenant faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" are spoken of as if they were living people who could protect the writer. AT: "I want your covenant faithfulness and your trustworthiness to always preserve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Troubles that cannot be numbered surround me
tn.text: Here troubles are spoken of as if they were objects that surround and trap the speaker. AT: "there are more troubles around me than I can count" or "more troubles come to me than I can count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is stated in negative form to intensify the number.See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:040:005|40:5]]. AT: "that are vast in number" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This refers to the consequences of his sin. AT: "the consequences of my iniquities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer's iniquities are spoken of as if they were his enemies who were harming him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: I am no longer able to see anything
tn.text: Versions differ in how to understand this difficult passage. It may mean that the speaker is crying so much that he cannot see anything because of his tears.
Here "heart" refers to the writer's inner confidence. AT: "I am very discouraged" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let them ... who pursue my life to take it away
tn.text: This can be reordered and stated in active form. AT: "Please make those who are trying to kill me become shamed and disappointed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: who pursue my life to take it away
tn.text: Here "pursue my life" means they desire to kill the writer. AT: "who are trying to kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let them ... who delight in hurting me
tn.text: This can be reordered and stated in active form. AT: "Please stop those who delight in hurting me and dishonor them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
To be stopped or thwarted is spoken of as being turned back from their attack. AT: "stopped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Let them ... who say to me, "Aha, aha!"
tn.text: "Let those who say to me, 'Aha, aha!' be shocked because of their shame"

tn.ref: Let them be shocked because of their shame
tn.text: "I hope that they will be shocked when you shame them"

tn.ref: those who say to me, "Aha, aha!"
tn.text: "Aha, aha!" is something people say when they are ridiculing someone. If your language has something that people say when ridiculing someone, it can be used here. This can also be translated with a verb like "ridicule."
These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the intensity of joy. AT: "be very joyful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as an action. AT: "love you because you saved them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
These words mean the same thing and emphasize how helpless the writer is. AT: "very needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"the Lord cares for me"

tn.ref: You are my help ... you come to my rescue
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"You are the one who helps me"
"you come to save me"
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "respond quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
